source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Awn inserted less than 1.2 mm from lemma apex; inflorescence dense or open, sometimes drooping
Awn inserted at least 1.2 mm from lemma apex; inflorescence normally erect, moderately to quite dense

Lemma usually scabrous-pubescent (nearly smooth in a rare alpine variant); awn distinctly scabrous or pubescent in the lower, thicker, strongly twisted column section, once or twice bent; glumes acute
Lemma smooth, glabrous; awn glabrous or minutely scabrous, fine throughout, (not obviously divided into a thicker, strongly twisted column section and finer bristle), sinuous; glumes narrow-acuminate
Spikelet less than 4 mm long; inflorescence usually contracted and spike-like
Spikelet more than 4 mm long; inflorescence contracted or open
Lemma shorter than or equal to lower glume; inflorescence usually contracted and erect
Lemma longer than lower (and often also upper) glume; inflorescence usually loose, often drooping
Lemma and (at least lower part of) awn scabrous-pubescent, 6–8 mm and 15–30 mm long respectively; awn inserted at least 1 mm from lemma apex
Lemma and awn glabrous (but often finely scabrous), mostly 4.5–6 mm and 10–25 mm long respectively; awn inserted 0–1 mm from lemma apex
Lemma distinctly scabrous; awn bigeniculate with a distinct column, thickened and strongly twisted at maturity; longest callus hairs 1–1.5 mm long
Lemma smooth to minutely scabrous; awn sinuate to weakly bigeniculate with an indistinct column, not or barely twisted at maturity; longest callus hairs to 1 mm long
Culms to 70 cm high; inflorescence rather sparse, few-(<50-)flowered, to c. 20 cm long; leaf-blades rarely wider than 3 mm; montane to subalpine areas of eastern ranges
Culms 100–130 cm high; inflorescence contracted to some degree, many-(>100-)flowered, 25–35 cm long; leaf-blades mostly wider than 4 mm; apparently rare species of near-coastal, eastern lowlands
